<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Interactions of dithioether ligands L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, L<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> and L<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup> (L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>1,3-bis(4-(3-pyridyl) pyrimidin-2-ylthio) propane; L<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>1,3-bis[4-(3-pyridyl) pyrimidinyl thiomethyl]benzene; L<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>1,4-bis[4-(3-pyridyl)pyrimidinylthiomethyl] benzene) with Mn(II) ions and NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>SCN in an analogous way led to the formation of two discrete mononuclear complexes and a one-dimensional chain, respectively, which may be attributed to the different flexibility and positional isomerism of the ligands.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

Interactions of dithioether ligands L2, L4 and L5 (L2 =1,3-bis(4-(3-pyridyl) pyrimidin-2-ylthio) propane; L4 =1,3-bis[4-(3-pyridyl) pyrimidinyl thiomethyl]benzene; L5 =1,4-bis[4-(3-pyridyl)pyrimidinylthiomethyl] benzene) with Mn(II) ions and NH4SCN in an analogous way led to the formation of two discrete mononuclear complexes and a one-dimensional chain, respectively, which may be attributed to the different flexibility and positional isomerism of the ligands.

</ce:simple-para><ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Crystal engineering of coordination compounds has attracted a great deal of attention in the recent years because of their potential as functional materials . One of the most efficient and powerful strategy for constructing such compounds is directed self-assembly of designed organic ligands and inorganic metal ions. However, the predictability of these structures is still a great challenge because the assembly progress is highly influenced by several factors, such as coordination geometry of the metal, nature of the ligands, solvent system, metal-to-ligand ratio, template, pH value and counterions. Thus, systematic researches are required for understanding the roles of the factors in the formation of complexes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

      

Introduction

Crystal engineering of coordination compounds has attracted a great deal of attention in the recent years because of their potential as functional materials . One of the most efficient and powerful strategy for constructing such compounds is directed self-assembly of designed organic ligands and inorganic metal ions. However, the predictability of these structures is still a great challenge because the assembly progress is highly influenced by several factors, such as coordination geometry of the metal, nature of the ligands, solvent system, metal-to-ligand ratio, template, pH value and counterions. Thus, systematic researches are required for understanding the roles of the factors in the formation of complexes.

elements.content:
<ce:figure>
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:para view="all">Meanwhile, rational design and assembly of sophisticated supramolecular architectures with heterocyclic thiolates or thioethers by the metal–ligand interactions is a topic of considerable interest for their fascinating structural topologies and potential uses as functional materials in recent years .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Meanwhile, rational design and assembly of sophisticated supramolecular architectures with heterocyclic thiolates or thioethers by the metal-ligand interactions is a topic of considerable interest for their fascinating structural topologies and potential uses as functional materials in recent years .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In our previous work, a series of flexible dithioether ligands (shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch1"></ce:float-anchor>) were treated with d<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> metal ions to yield discrete macrocyclic complexes, 1D polymers, 2D and 3D coordinated frameworks.  These dithioether ligands reveal some unique features: 1) multiple metal binding sites, such as N atoms from heterocyclic donors and S atoms of the thioethers in a ligand molecule; 2) the tunable flexibility of –(S–R–S)- (<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>alkyl and aryl groups) chains; 3) the tunable positional isomerism, including the central phenyl with o-, p- and m-disubstituted groups and the pyridyl rings of the two arms with different N-positions, which are helpful to understand the influences of the nature of the ligands on the crystal structures of the corresponding coordination compounds. We have used L<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> and L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> ligands to self-assemble with ZnI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, CdI<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, Zn(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and Cd(ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, in order to study the influence of the flexibility of the dithioether ligands on the crystal structures.  In our continuing attempts to research the crystal engineering of this series of dithioether ligands, L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, L<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> and L<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup> with different flexibility and positional isomerism have been selected to self-assmble Mn(II) complexes with thiocyanate as the terminal ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In our previous work, a series of flexible dithioether ligands (shown in  ) were treated with d10 metal ions to yield discrete macrocyclic complexes, 1D polymers, 2D and 3D coordinated frameworks.  These dithioether ligands reveal some unique features: 1) multiple metal binding sites, such as N atoms from heterocyclic donors and S atoms of the thioethers in a ligand molecule; 2) the tunable flexibility of -(S-R-S)- (R =alkyl and aryl groups) chains; 3) the tunable positional isomerism, including the central phenyl with o-, p- and m-disubstituted groups and the pyridyl rings of the two arms with different N-positions, which are helpful to understand the influences of the nature of the ligands on the crystal structures of the corresponding coordination compounds. We have used L1 and L2 ligands to self-assemble with ZnI2, CdI2, Zn(ClO4)2 and Cd(ClO4)2, in order to study the influence of the flexibility of the dithioether ligands on the crystal structures.  In our continuing attempts to research the crystal engineering of this series of dithioether ligands, L2, L4 and L5 with different flexibility and positional isomerism have been selected to self-assmble Mn(II) complexes with thiocyanate as the terminal ligands.

Experimental section

Materials and measurements

All solvents and reagents were of analytical grade and used without further purification. 1,3-bis(4-(3-pyridyl) pyrimidin-2-ylthio) propane (L2) and 1,3-bis [4-(3-pyridyl)pyrimidinylthiomethyl]benzene (L4) were prepared in the same manner as reported previously .

</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Similarly to the literature method , L<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup> was made as following. To a solution of 4-(pyridin-3-yl) pyrimidine-2-thiol (1.89<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and sodium hydroxide (0.40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in dry ethanol (150<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL), 1,4-bis(bromomethyl)benzene (1.32<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in CHCl<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> (10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was added. Preparation of ligands L5 

Similarly to the literature method , L5 was made as following. To a solution of 4-(pyridin-3-yl) pyrimidine-2-thiol (1.89g, 10mmol) and sodium hydroxide (0.40g, 10mmol) in dry ethanol (150mL), 1,4-bis(bromomethyl)benzene (1.32g, 5mmol) in CHCl3 (10mL) was added. The mixture was stirred and refluxed for 6h. After cooled, yellow precipitates were filtered, washed by water and ethanol, and dried in vacuum. Yield 54.3%, M.p. 179-181°C. Anal. Calcd for C26H20N6S2: C, 64.98; H, 4.19; N, 17.49. Found: C, 64.91; H, 4.39; N, 17.43%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 1590 (w), 1564 (s), 1539 (m), 1479 (w), 1419 (w), 1406 (m), 1342 (w), 1319 (m), 1214 (m), 1196 (m), 1026 (w), 826 (w), 815 (w), 704(w). ESI-MS: 503.0 (100%) [L+Na]+, 481.3 (45%)[L+H]+. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 8.78 (d, 2H, pyridyl-H), 8.67 (d, 2H, pyrimidyl-H), 8.44 (d, 2H, pyrimidyl-H), 8.05 (d, 2H, pyridyl-H), 7.86 (t, 2H, pyridyl-H), 7.45 (s, 4H, aryl-H), 7.43 (d, 2H, pyridyl-H), 4.52 (s, 4H, methylene-H).

Preparation of complexes

 1 was prepared by adding a methanol (20mL) solution of NH4SCN (1mmol, 0.076g) to a hot methanol (60mL) solution of MnCl2⋅2H2O (0.081g 0.5mmol) and L2 (0.209g, 0.5mmol). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique with the SHELXTL program package. Anisotropic thermal parameters were applied to all the non-hydrogen atoms. The organic hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically (C-H 0.96Å); the hydrogen atoms of aqua and hydroxyl were located from difference maps and refined with isotropic temperature factors. <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were synthesized in an analogous method. Interestingly, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are both mononuclear complexes, while 3 is a one-dimensional chain, which can be attributed to the different flexibility, rigidity and positional isomerism of these three ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and spectral characterization

 1-3 were synthesized in an analogous method. Interestingly, 1 and 2 are both mononuclear complexes, while 3 is a one-dimensional chain, which can be attributed to the different flexibility, rigidity and positional isomerism of these three ligands.

In the 1400–1602<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> region, the absorption bands are in accordance with the skeletal vibrations of aromatic rings for these complexes. The weak absorption band appearing in the 800–820<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> region can be assigned to the C–S stretching vibration. The asymmetric unit of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> contains one L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> ligand, half of a Mn(II) ion, one coordinated water molecule and one terminal thiocyanato ligand (

elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallographic studies of complexes

[Mn(L2)2(H2O)2 (SCN)2] (1)

Single-crystal XRD study has revealed that [Mn(L2)2(H2O)2(SCN)2] (1) crystallizes in a triclinic system with space group P-1. The asymmetric unit of 1 contains one L2 ligand, half of a Mn(II) ion, one coordinated water molecule and one terminal thiocyanato ligand ( ).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The complex is mononuclear, in which the Mn(II) ion is coordinated by two pyridyl N atoms from two ligands, two water molecules and two thiocyanato ligands in an elongated octahedral coordination geometry. It is worthy noting that the full dithioether molecule acts as an effectively monodentate ligand in the <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic> configuration to bind a metal ion in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Two pyridyl rings connected with the same metal center are coplanar each other.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The complex is mononuclear, in which the Mn(II) ion is coordinated by two pyridyl N atoms from two ligands, two water molecules and two thiocyanato ligands in an elongated octahedral coordination geometry. It is worthy noting that the full dithioether molecule acts as an effectively monodentate ligand in the cis configuration to bind a metal ion in 1. Two pyridyl rings connected with the same metal center are coplanar each other.

[Mn(L4)2(H2O)2(SCN)2]⋅(CH3OH)2⋅(H2O)1.66 (2)

By replacing L2 with L4, [Mn(L4)2(H2O)2(SCN)2]⋅(CH3OH)2⋅(H2O)1.66 (2) was obtained. 2 also crystallizes in a triclinic system of space group P-1. The asymmetric unit of 2 contains one monodentate ligand, half of a Mn(II) ion, one thiocyanato and one coordination water molecule as well as one free methanol molecule and disordered lattice water molecules, as shown in  .

Meanwhile, two pyridyl rings connected with the same metal atom are also coplanar each other.</ce:para>

It is noted that each L<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup> in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> acts as a <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′-bidentate ligand to link two Mn(II) atoms to form a one-dimensional chain (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>). Furthermore, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig6"></ce:float-anchor>, adjacent chains are joined together via O1w N2a (symmetry code: <ce:italic>x</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>y</ce:italic>, −1<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.2"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>) hydrogen bonds with the O N distance of 2.866(6)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The free water molecules are stabled to coordinated water molecules via intramolecular hydrogen bonds (O1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>W O2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>W 2.872(10)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
{[Mn(L5)(H2O)2(SCN)2] (H2O)}n (3)

Self-assembly of Mn(SCN)2 with L5 generates a polymeric complex 3, which crystallizes in the space group P-1, consisting of half of a Mn(II) ion, half of one L5 ligand, one thiocyanato ligand and one coordination water molecule as well as one free water molecule in an asymmetric unit ( ). The coordination environment of Mn(II) ion is an elongated octahedron, equatorially coordinated by two N atoms from two thiocyanato ligands and two O atoms from two water molecules and apically occupied by two N atoms from two L5 ligands. The Mn1-N1 distance is 2.308(4)Å, being comparable with those in 1 and 2 (2.320(3)Å for 1, 2.268(5)Å for 2). It is noted that each L5 in 3 acts as a N,N'-bidentate ligand to link two Mn(II) atoms to form a one-dimensional chain ( ). Furthermore, as shown in  , adjacent chains are joined together via O1w N2a (symmetry code: x, y, -1+ z) hydrogen bonds with the O N distance of 2.866(6)Å. The free water molecules are stabled to coordinated water molecules via intramolecular hydrogen bonds (O1W O2W 2.872(10)Å).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In addition, L<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup> in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> adopts a <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> conformation to open its two heterocyclic arms to connect metal ions, which are on the opposite side of the central phenyl ring. The two pyridyl rings connected with the same metal atom are also coplanar with each other.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In addition, L5 in 3 adopts a trans conformation to open its two heterocyclic arms to connect metal ions, which are on the opposite side of the central phenyl ring. The two pyridyl rings connected with the same metal atom are also coplanar with each other.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Influences of the nature of the ligands on the crystal structures</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">For complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the central Mn(II) ions have the same coordination modes with an elongated octahedral configuration, coordinated by two N atoms from two thiocyanato ligands, two O atoms from two water molecules and two N atoms from two dithioether ligands. The difference is that L<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup> in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> acts as a <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′-bidentate ligand to link two Mn(II) centers, while L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> in 1 and L<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> both act as a monodentate ligand to link one Mn(II) center with the N atom on one arm not participating in coordination. Meanwhile, L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> adopts a <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic> configuration, while L<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and L<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup> in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> have a <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> conformation. For L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, L<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> and L<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>, the N atoms in the pyridyl rings are all in the <ce:italic>p</ce:italic>-position of pyrimidine rings, and the difference is the central –[S–R–S]- sections. Moreover, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are obtained in the analogous method. Therefore, the formation of different compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> can be attributed to the flexibility and positional isomerism of ligands.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Influences of the nature of the ligands on the crystal structures

For complexes 1-3, the central Mn(II) ions have the same coordination modes with an elongated octahedral configuration, coordinated by two N atoms from two thiocyanato ligands, two O atoms from two water molecules and two N atoms from two dithioether ligands. The difference is that L5 in 3 acts as a N,N'-bidentate ligand to link two Mn(II) centers, while L2 in 1 and L4 in 2 both act as a monodentate ligand to link one Mn(II) center with the N atom on one arm not participating in coordination. Meanwhile, L2 in 1 adopts a cis configuration, while L4 in 2 and L5 in 3 have a trans conformation. For L2, L4 and L5, the N atoms in the pyridyl rings are all in the p-position of pyrimidine rings, and the difference is the central -[S-R-S]- sections. Moreover, 1, 2 and 3 are obtained in the analogous method. Therefore, the formation of different compound 1-3 can be attributed to the flexibility and positional isomerism of ligands.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In this study, three new complexes with different architectures, [Mn(L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Mn(L<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]·(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">1.66</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), {[Mn(L<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(SCN)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) were constructed from L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>, L<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> and L<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup>, respectively. The coordination of Mn(II) ions with L<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> and L<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup> yield two discrete mononuclear complexes, while with L<ce:sup loc="post">5</ce:sup> produce a one-dimensional chain. The present study demonstrates that the flexibility and the nature of positional isomerism of ligands are suggested to be crucial factors for the formation of the structures.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this study, three new complexes with different architectures, [Mn(L2)2(H2O)2(SCN)2] (1), [Mn(L4)2(H2O)2(SCN)2]⋅(CH3OH)2⋅(H2O)1.66 (2), {[Mn(L5)(H2O)2(SCN)2] (H2O)} n  (3) were constructed from L2, L4 and L5, respectively. The coordination of Mn(II) ions with L2 and L4 yield two discrete mononuclear complexes, while with L5 produce a one-dimensional chain. The present study demonstrates that the flexibility and the nature of positional isomerism of ligands are suggested to be crucial factors for the formation of the structures.

Preparation of ligands L5 

Similarly to the literature method , L5 was made as following. To a solution of 4-(pyridin-3-yl) pyrimidine-2-thiol (1.89g, 10mmol) and sodium hydroxide (0.40g, 10mmol) in dry ethanol (150mL), 1,4-bis(bromomethyl)benzene (1.32g, 5mmol) in CHCl3 (10mL) was added. The mixture was stirred and refluxed for 6h. After cooled, yellow precipitates were filtered, washed by water and ethanol, and dried in vacuum. Yield 54.3%, M.p. 179-181°C. Anal. Calcd for C26H20N6S2: C, 64.98; H, 4.19; N, 17.49. Found: C, 64.91; H, 4.39; N, 17.43%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 1590 (w), 1564 (s), 1539 (m), 1479 (w), 1419 (w), 1406 (m), 1342 (w), 1319 (m), 1214 (m), 1196 (m), 1026 (w), 826 (w), 815 (w), 704(w). ESI-MS: 503.0 (100%) [L+Na]+, 481.3 (45%)[L+H]+. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 8.78 (d, 2H, pyridyl-H), 8.67 (d, 2H, pyrimidyl-H), 8.44 (d, 2H, pyrimidyl-H), 8.05 (d, 2H, pyridyl-H), 7.86 (t, 2H, pyridyl-H), 7.45 (s, 4H, aryl-H), 7.43 (d, 2H, pyridyl-H), 4.52 (s, 4H, methylene-H).

Preparation of complexes

[Mn(L2)2(H2O)2(SCN)2] (1)

 1 was prepared by adding a methanol (20mL) solution of NH4SCN (1mmol, 0.076g) to a hot methanol (60mL) solution of MnCl2⋅2H2O (0.081g 0.5mmol) and L2 (0.209g, 0.5mmol). The resulting colorless solution was stirred and refluxed for 1h, then filtered after cooled. The filtrate was left evaporated in the air at room temperature. Colorless crystals of 1 were obtained. Yield: 58%. Anal. Calcd. for C44H40MnN14O2S6: C, 50.61; H, 3.86; N, 18.78. Found: C, 50.65; H, 3.94; N, 18.74%. Main IR (KBr, cm-1): 3144(w), 2071(vs), 1558(s), 1542(s), 1479(w), 1404(s), 1349(m), 1326(m), 1202(m), 1181(m), 831(w), 723(w), 700(w).

[Mn(L4)2(H2O)2(SCN)2]⋅(CH3OH)2⋅(H2O)1.66 (2)

The reaction was carried out in a method similar to that for 1 by replacing L2 with L4 (0.083g, 0.25mmol) for 2. Yield: 73%. Anal. Calcd. for C56H55.32MnN14O5.66S6: C, 53.28; H, 4.42; N, 15.53. Found: C, 53.35; H, 4.44; N, 15.44%. Main IR (KBr, cm-1): 3240(bm), 2084(vs), 1602(w), 1564(s), 1542 (s), 1480(w), 1397(s), 1350(s), 1324(m), 1202(m), 1179(w), 831(w), 807(w), 700(w).

{[Mn(L5)(H2O)2(SCN)2](H2O)}n (3)

An analogous way to 1 was used by replacing L2 with L5 (0.240g, 0.5mmol). Yield: 69%. Anal. Calcd. for C28H26MnN8O3S4: C, 47.65; H, 3.71; N, 15.88. Found: C, 47.63; H, 3.84; N, 15.84%. Main IR (KBr, cm-1): 3418(bw), 2066(vs), 1599(w), 1564(s), 1542(s), 1483(w), 1406(m), 1347(m), 1323(w), 1202(w), 1181(w), 837(w), 724(w), 700(w).
